question_text: In the context of spray combustion simulations using the level set method, what numerical challenges arise from evaporation processes, and how does the Ghost Fluid Method (GFM) address these challenges according to the paper?
standard_answer: The evaporation process in spray combustion introduces significant numerical challenges when using the level set method for interface capturing. Specifically, evaporation adds new jump conditions across the interface to the governing equations, which further increases the complexity of the system. These jump conditions must account for mass, momentum, and energy conservation across the phase interface, requiring careful numerical treatment. The Ghost Fluid Method (GFM) has been incorporated to address these challenges by providing a framework for imposing jump conditions sharply in the level set framework. Since the level set method implicitly defines convoluted interfaces, directly imposing jump conditions on the interface is difficult; instead, they must be applied to adjacent cells. GFM enables this by defining ghost values that allow accurate discretization of the discontinuities without numerical smearing, ensuring proper treatment of the additional complexity introduced by evaporation processes in spray combustion simulations.
